skos.definition: Presence of air in the pleural space causing partial or complete lung collapse, classified as spontaneous (primary or secondary), traumatic, or iatrogenic, with tension pneumothorax representing a life-threatening emergency.
skos.scopeNote: Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention

content.title: Pneumothorax
content.summary: Pneumothorax is air in the pleural space causing lung collapse. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax occurs in healthy individuals (typically tall, thin young men), while secondary pneumothorax complicates underlying lung disease. Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate decompression. Management ranges from observation to chest tube placement depending on size, symptoms, and underlying lung disease.
key_points: Primary spontaneous: no underlying lung disease; tall, thin young males; subpleural blebs
Secondary spontaneous: underlying lung disease (COPD, cystic fibrosis); higher morbidity
Tension pneumothorax: one-way valve effect with hemodynamic compromise; needle decompression first
Symptoms: sudden pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea; may be absent in small PTX
CXR: visceral pleural line with absent lung markings; upright expiratory view increases sensitivity
Small primary PTX (<2 cm rim): observation with supplemental O2
Large or symptomatic: chest tube or needle aspiration
content.statement: Pneumothorax results from disruption of either the visceral pleura (allowing air from the lung) or chest wall/parietal pleura (allowing atmospheric air). Recognition of tension pneumothorax and immediate decompression is life-saving. Management of non-tension pneumothorax depends on clinical context, size, symptoms, and underlying lung disease.

explanation.intuition: Think of the lung as a balloon inside a sealed box (thorax). Normally, negative pressure in the box keeps the balloon inflated. A pneumothorax is like poking a hole that lets air into the box - the lung 'deflates' because the negative pressure is lost. In tension pneumothorax, the hole acts like a one-way valve, pumping more and more air into the box with each breath until it crushes the heart and other lung.
explanation.key_insight: The key distinction is between simple pneumothorax (air enters but pressure equalizes) and tension pneumothorax (one-way valve causes progressive air accumulation). Tension PTX causes mediastinal shift, compresses the vena cava, and causes obstructive shock - it kills by preventing venous return to the heart, not by hypoxia alone.
explanation.technical_details: Pleural pressure is normally -5 cm H2O at FRC. Air entry eliminates this negative pressure, causing lung collapse due to elastic recoil. In tension PTX, intrapleural pressure exceeds atmospheric pressure, causing mediastinal shift, decreased venous return, and obstructive shock. High-flow supplemental oxygen accelerates reabsorption by creating a nitrogen gradient (pleural air is ~80% N2; oxygen replaces N2 in blood, promoting diffusion).

definitions_glossary.primary_spontaneous_PTX: Pneumothorax without underlying lung disease; associated with apical subpleural blebs
definitions_glossary.secondary_spontaneous_PTX: Pneumothorax complicating underlying lung disease; higher morbidity and recurrence
definitions_glossary.tension_pneumothorax: Progressive air accumulation due to one-way valve; causes hemodynamic collapse
definitions_glossary.traumatic_pneumothorax: Result of penetrating or blunt chest trauma
definitions_glossary.iatrogenic_pneumothorax: Complication of procedures (central line, thoracentesis, lung biopsy, mechanical ventilation)
definitions_glossary.visceral_pleura: Membrane covering lung surface; rupture allows air from lung into pleural space
definitions_glossary.parietal_pleura: Membrane lining chest wall; penetration allows atmospheric air entry
definitions_glossary.needle_decompression: Emergency procedure inserting large-bore needle into 2nd intercostal space MCL for tension PTX
definitions_glossary.chest_tube: Tube thoracostomy draining air/fluid from pleural space; definitive treatment
definitions_glossary.needle_aspiration: Alternative to chest tube for primary spontaneous PTX; aspirate air with catheter
definitions_glossary.pleurodesis: Procedure to fuse pleural layers preventing recurrence; chemical (talc) or surgical
definitions_glossary.catamenial_pneumothorax: Recurrent PTX coinciding with menstruation; associated with thoracic endometriosis
definitions_glossary.subpleural_bleb: Small subpleural air collection; rupture causes primary spontaneous PTX
definitions_glossary.Heimlich_valve: One-way valve allowing air out of chest; alternative to water-seal drainage

pathophysiology.mechanism: Air enters pleural space through defect in visceral pleura (lung air) or parietal pleura/chest wall (atmospheric air). Loss of negative intrapleural pressure causes lung collapse. In tension PTX, one-way valve allows air entry but not exit, causing progressive pressure increase.

spontaneous.primary: No underlying lung disease; subpleural blebs in upper lobes; tall thin young males; smoking increases risk 20×
spontaneous.secondary: Underlying lung disease: COPD (most common), cystic fibrosis, Pneumocystis pneumonia, LAM, malignancy

classification.traumatic: Penetrating (stab, gunshot) or blunt (rib fractures, barotrauma) chest injury
classification.iatrogenic: Central line placement (subclavian > IJ), thoracentesis, lung biopsy, mechanical ventilation
classification.catamenial: Recurrent PTX within 72 hours of menstruation; thoracic endometriosis

symptoms: Dyspnea (may be minimal in small PTX)
May be asymptomatic in small primary PTX
signs: Decreased breath sounds on affected side
Tracheal deviation AWAY from affected side (tension PTX)

tension_pneumothorax.mechanism: One-way valve causes progressive air accumulation
tension_pneumothorax.signs: Hypotension, tachycardia, distended neck veins, tracheal deviation, cyanosis
tension_pneumothorax.diagnosis: CLINICAL - do not wait for imaging
tension_pneumothorax.treatment: Immediate needle decompression followed by chest tube

chest_xray.findings: Visceral pleural line with absent lung markings peripheral to it
chest_xray.optimization: Upright position; expiratory film increases sensitivity
chest_xray.size_measurement: Distance from apex to cupola or lateral rim measurement

ct_chest.indication: Uncertain diagnosis, suspected underlying lung disease, recurrent PTX evaluation
ct_chest.advantages: More sensitive than CXR; detects small PTX, bullae, underlying pathology

ultrasound.findings: Absent lung sliding, absent comet tail artifacts, lung point

size_classification.small: <2 cm rim at hilum (BTS) or <3 cm apex to cupola (ACCP)
size_classification.large: ≥2 cm rim or ≥3 cm apex to cupola

tension_pneumothorax.immediate: Needle decompression: 14-16G needle at 2nd ICS midclavicular line (or 5th ICS anterior axillary line)
tension_pneumothorax.definitive: Chest tube placement immediately after needle decompression

primary_spontaneous.small_asymptomatic: Observation with high-flow O2 (accelerates reabsorption); repeat CXR in 3-6 hours
primary_spontaneous.large_or_symptomatic: Needle aspiration (first-line in UK guidelines) or small-bore chest tube
primary_spontaneous.recurrence_prevention: VATS with bullectomy and pleurodesis after 2nd episode or first recurrence

secondary_spontaneous.all_cases: Chest tube drainage (not aspiration); more unstable due to underlying lung disease
secondary_spontaneous.recurrence_prevention: More aggressive - pleurodesis after first episode often indicated

iatrogenic.symptomatic: Aspiration or chest tube depending on size

chest_tube_management: Connect to water-seal drainage system (-20 cm H2O suction initially)
Monitor for air leak, lung re-expansion
Remove when lung fully expanded and no air leak for 24-48 hours

primary_spontaneous.recurrence: 30% after first episode; 60% after second; 80% after third

secondary_spontaneous.mortality: Higher (5-15%) due to underlying lung disease

learning_objectives: Differentiate primary from secondary spontaneous pneumothorax
Recognize the clinical features of tension pneumothorax and perform emergency decompression
Interpret chest X-ray findings in pneumothorax including size estimation
Outline management based on type, size, and symptoms
Describe indications for pleurodesis and surgical intervention
List common iatrogenic causes of pneumothorax
clinical_pearls: Tension PTX is a CLINICAL diagnosis - if suspected, decompress first, image later
Tall, thin, young male smoker with sudden chest pain + dyspnea = primary spontaneous PTX
COPD patient with sudden worsening = always consider secondary spontaneous PTX
High-flow O2 accelerates PTX reabsorption 4× by creating N2 gradient
Always check CXR after subclavian central line placement
Recurrence is common (30% after first primary PTX) - counsel patients

common_question_stems: Tall thin young man with sudden chest pain and absent breath sounds
Trauma patient with hypotension and tracheal deviation
COPD patient with sudden dyspnea and hyperresonance
Post-central line placement with new dyspnea
exam_tips: Tension PTX = needle decompression BEFORE imaging
Secondary PTX = chest tube (more aggressive than primary)

teaching_cases.scenario: 22-year-old tall thin male smoker with sudden right-sided pleuritic chest pain and mild dyspnea. Decreased breath sounds on right. CXR shows 2.5 cm apical pneumothorax.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Primary spontaneous pneumothorax, large (>2 cm), symptomatic
teaching_cases.management: Needle aspiration or small-bore chest tube, smoking cessation counseling, explain recurrence risk
